note.p: Joseph Plummer Schooley was a Union officer during the Civil War and early part of Reconstruction in the South.

Born on August 29, 1832, in Manchester, Indiana, Schooley moved to Illinois with his young wife, Ellen Bliven Clarke, in the 1850s. He volunteered for Union military service when the Civil War broke out in 1861 and enlisted in the Seventy-sixth Illinois Infantry Regiment. He reached the rank of sergeant major before resigning from that regiment in 1864 to be commissioned as an officer in the Fourth Mississippi Infantry Regiment (African Descent)â€”a regiment comprising primarily of former slaves, commanded by white officers. The regiment was renamed the Sixty-sixth United States Colored Troops in March 1864. Schooley held the rank of captain in the unit when the war ended in 1865. He remained with the regiment during its occupation duty in Mississippi for several months after the war. Schooley separated from the Union army around 1866 and returned to his family in Illinois and moved to Missouri.

His first wife passed away in September 1871, and Schooley married Mary Etta White that in December same year. He had a total of twelve children from the two marriages. Schooley died on December 4, 1895, in Austin, Missouri. He is buried in the Austin town cemetery.
Joseph Plummer Schooley belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Lauderdale County, Meridian was founded in 1854 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: United States--United States Military Telegraph Office (Washington, D.C.)
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. Federal Government
Organizations -- Military Organizations

gloss.p: Located in the War Department building in Washington, D. C., the United States Military Telegraph Office was a centralized office created in 1861. The United States Military Telegraph Office served as the headquarters for the United States Military Corps where ciphers coded and decoded messages, maintaining communications between the federal government in Washington D. C. and the commanding officers of the Union Army on the warfront. (Wikipedia; "The War Effort: The Telegraph Office," Mr. Lincoln's White House)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Clark Collection. Telegram from United States Army Lieutenant H. S. Buck at Meridian, Mississippi, to Captain J. P. Schooley, informing him that stores would be shipped in the morning.

element.value: Mississippi Department of Archives and History.

div.fw: Telegram from Lieutenant H. S. Buck to Captain J. P. Schooley; January 1865
div.p:
DEPARTMENT OF THE GULF,
U. S. Military Telegraph Office,
Will Commence shipping stores tomorrow morning & will Continue daily until estimate is fieled there is no sugar on your estimate for the first fifty thosand do you wish anyâ€”
